definitions.definition: a plan that lists all the work that you have to do and when you must do each thing
definitions.sensetop: on scheduleahead of schedulebehind scheduleaccording to schedule

examples.text: I have a **hectic schedule** for the next few days.
a busy/gruelling/punishing schedule
We're working to a **tight schedule** *(= we have a lot of things to do in a short time)*.
He has taken some time out of his busy schedule to talk to us.
They have a very flexible **work schedule**.
I have no time available in my regular schedule.
Filming began on schedule *(= at the planned time)*.
The project will be completed on schedule this summer.
The new bridge has been finished two years ahead of schedule.
The tunnel project has already fallen behind schedule.
At this stage everything is going according to schedule *(= as planned)*.
We are trying desperately to **keep to** our **schedule**.
The countries have yet to set the schedule for the next round of talks.
Allow time in the schedule for sickness.
I'm trying to fit everything into my busy schedule.
She has a very demanding schedule.
We had to work a lot of overtime to meet the strict production schedule.
We're five days off schedule.

definitions.definition: a chart showing the times at which trains, buses and planes leave and arrive

examples.text: Connor checked the bus schedules for the day.
disruptions to flight schedules caused by the strike

definitions.definition: a chart or plan of the classes that a student or teacher has in school each week

examples.text: Besides a full school schedule, Kayla's week is jam-packed with other activities.
What's your schedule like next semester?

definitions.definition: a list of the television and radio programmes that are on a particular channel and the times that they start

examples.text: The channel's schedules are filled with old films and repeats.
Channel 4 has published its spring schedules.
The show trebled ratings for the channel's afternoon schedule.

definitions.definition: a written list of things, for example prices, rates or conditions

examples.text: tax schedules

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘scroll, explanatory note, appendix’): from Old French cedule, from late Latin schedula ‘slip of paper’, diminutive of scheda, from Greek skhedē ‘papyrus leaf’. The verb dates from the mid 19th cent.
